abstract.text: Use a strings dictionary file to ensure correct localization of strings that contain

inlineContent.text: In Xcode 15 and later, string catalogs are the recommended way to localize strings that contain plurals. In earlier versions of Xcode, use strings and
files. For more information about string catalogs, see
Languages have different grammatical rules for handling plurals of nouns and units.
So if you localize formatted strings that contain variable amounts, use a
file to provide a different translation for each plural form in the language.
For example, if you pass the
formatted string to the
macro or similar API, such as the
structure, you can use the a
file to return different versions of the string. In English, you can return
or
when
is
, and
when
is greater
than
. For other languages, the
file can have more or fewer plural
variants of a formatted string.
Xcode automatically handles
files for you when you export and import
localizations. However, you need to know the format of a
file to localize
it in the development language and other languages if you don’t use a localization
service.

content.text: Add a strings dictionary file to your project

inlineContent.text: To add a
file to your project, choose File > New > File. In the sheet
that appears, select the platform, enter
in the Filter field, select Stringsdict
File, and click Next. In the dialog that appears, enter a name for the file, choose
a location, and click Create.
A
file is a resource file in your project, but Xcode doesn’t automatically
localize it. While the file is in a selected state in the Project navigator, open
the inspector, and click Localize under Localization. In the dialog that appears,
choose a language and click Localize. Choose Base to localize the file in all languages.
If you previously added localizations to your project, select the other localizations
in the inspector under Localization. If you select multiple localizations, the
file becomes a group in the Project navigator that contains a version for each language.
Later when you add more localizations, be sure to include the
file
when you select resources for the localization.

content.text: Localize the strings dictionary file in the development language

inlineContent.text: Next, add the plural rules and variants to the development language version of the
file.
In the Project navigator, select the
file. If it appears as a group,
select the development language version of the file (the language appears in parentheses).
Because a
file is a property list, it appears in the property editor
by default. To edit the
file using the source editor, Control-click
it and choose Open As > Source Code.
A new
file contains a dictionary with plural variants for a single
formatted string. For each formatted string in your app that contains a numeric value,
enter the formatted string as the key and a
plural variant
dictionary as the value
with the following key-value pairs:
Key
Value
A formatted string that contains variables. To replace the string with a plural rule, precede the variable with the %#@ characters and follow it by the @ character, as in
where
is the variable.
A dictionary that specifies the plural variants for a variable in the formatted string.
For example, enter separate dictionaries for the user-facing formatted strings you
use in your code. If the formatted string contains multiple variables, enter a separate
subdictionary for each variable. In the following
file, the formatted
strings are:
, and
The variable dictionary for each formatted string determines which string returns
from the
structure,
macro, or similar API in your code. It contains a key-value pair for each grammatical
plural variant in the language, called a
category
For example, the following
file with English localization contains
plural variants for the
, and
categories. For the
formatted string, the API returns
for
for
, and
for
values.
A variable dictionary can contain the following key-value pairs:
Key
Value
Specifies the type of language rule. The only possible value is
, which indicates a language plural variant.
A string format specifier for a number, as in the letter
for an integer.

inlineContent.code: zero, one, two, few, many, other

inlineContent.text: The formatted string for the language-specific plural category. Using the format specifier in the string is optional. The
category is a requirement.
The meaning of the plural categories is language-dependent, and not all languages
have the same categories. For example, the English language only requires the
and
categories to represent plural forms, and
is optional. Arabic
has different plural forms for the
, and
categories. Although Russian also uses the
category, the rules for which numbers
are in the
category aren’t the same as the Arabic rules.
For the categories and plural rules for each language, see

content.text: Localize the strings dictionary file in other languages

inlineContent.text: After you localize the
files in the development langauge and add the
other localizations to your project, you export the localizations.
When you export localizations, Xcode automatically adds the language-specific categories
for each formatted string to the exported XLIFF files. Localizers just need to enter
the translations for each category in the XLIFF file. Then when you import localizations,
Xcode updates the localized
files in your project.
For example, if you export a Russian localization containing the
formatted string in a
file, Xcode adds the
, and
categories to the Russian version of the XLIFF file. The localizer inserts the translations
and when you import the localization, the
file contains the correct
variable dictionary key-value pairs for Russian.
You can edit the
files in Xcode yourself, but keep in mind that all
of the categories are optional except the
category. Also the localized text
may be grammatically incorrect if you don’t supply a rule for all the language-specific
categories. Conversely, if you provide a rule for a category that a language doesn’t
use, the system ignores it and uses the
category format string instead.
Furthermore, using the
format specifier in the localized
formatted strings is optional. For example, the format string for the
category
in English can be
, while the
category can be
You can use the format specifier (
or spell out numbers (
in the plural
variants, but don’t use a numeric value (
) in the string because it may not have
the correct localization if the user changes regions.

abstract.text: Build, test, and submit your app with Apple’s integrated development environment.
Select the resources that you want to localize for each language and region you support.

Use a string catalog to translate text, handle plurals, and vary the text your app displays on specific devices.

Returns a localized version of a string from the default table, which Xcode autogenerates when exporting localizations.
